name: ocimum-tenuiflorum
edibility: A culinary herb especially in Asia used in the same ways as sweet basil though it is commonly cooked or used in teas rather than used raw.  Fragrant leaves have a spicy bite that is a mix of clove, mint, and basil flavor.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Purple-green to brown smooth to slightly pitted elliptical nutlets  0.8-1.2 mm long with numerous seeds inside.
flower-description: White, pale pink or lavender tiny tubular flowers with green or purple sepals  in terminal panicles or racemes that are 4-12 cm long.
leaf-description: Pungently fragrant pubescent leaves are simple, elliptic to oblong with serrate to entire margins.  Leaves are 1.5 to 3 inches long and .5 inches wide.  Hairs are on both sides but especially on veins on the underside.
stem-description: Highly pubescent square stems in purple or green.
uses: A plant used in the Hindu religion and Ayurvedic medicine to cleanse the body, and for stomach and skin issues.
